awd_titl_txt: Support for Doctoral Students from U.S. Universities to Attend the 12th International Conference on Educational Data Mining (EDM 2019)
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an award to support travel and a Doctoral Consortium at the 2019 Educational Data Mining (EDM) Conference for up to 10 doctoral students. The Doctoral Consortium provides a forum for mentoring and research collaborations with EDM participants. The doctoral students will be chosen through an application process. The selection committee will ensure that the selected students form a diverse group with respect to interests and with attention being paid for participation of underrepresented groups.

The Doctoral Consortium is a conference within the conference where each student is matched with a mentor. The students will share their research with their mentors, other experienced researchers, and other students as they pitch their research as a high-level overview. They will then get tailored advice and research contacts that will be valuable for their future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The original proposal seeks funding to support doctoral students from the United States to attend the 12th International Conference on Educational Data Mining (EDM 2019) and present their work in the doctoral consortium (DC) session. However, the total amount of $20K was more than enough to support student travels; therefore, we decided to use the remaining funds for later editions of EDM. PI Lan was the DC chair for EDM 2019 but was not in charge for later versions. Nevertheless, we contributed by coordinating with the EDM DC chairs in later years. However, dur to the COVID-19 pandemic, EDM was fully virtual for two years. The in-person event finally resumed in 2022 in Durham, UK, and then in 2023 in Bengalore, India, and in 2024 in Atlanta, GA. We reimbursed one student for EDM 2022 and two for EDM 2024.


Overall, we supported 8 doctoral students traveling to EDM and attending the DC. Many are from under-represented student populations. In each year, these students got an opportunity to engage in deep conversations with 10-20 senior figures in the field of Cyberlearning in a 2-hour session. Many kept up those connections, which continued into fruitful collaborations. These connections go a long way to help developing the next generation of Cyberlearning researchers.


Last Modified: 09/08/2024
Modified by: Shiting Lan
